Award.AwardTitle: Geometric Group Theory on the Gulf Coast
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal is to provide funding for the three annual meetings on Geometric Group Theory on the Gulf Coast (abbreviated G^3); the next conference will be held in Pensacola, FL on March 27-30, 2014. The last decade has seen intense interactions and cross-fertilization of geometric group theory with other parts of mathematics such as asymptotic and coarse geometry, operator algebras and Novikov type conjectures, analysis and dynamics on group boundaries, discrete groups and nonpositively curved spaces. These are separate fields yet they increasingly borrow techniques, examples, and insights from each other, and their richness and interplay feeds back to the geometric group theory, and provides strong motivation for its development. The intellectual goal of the conference is to assemble researchers from these neighboring fields, so they can share ideas and expertise while interacting with students and junior mathematicians.

The G^3 conference focuses on interactions of geometric group theory with other parts of mathematics. G^3 has been held annually since 1998 at various places on the Gulf Coast, and it has become an established and popular international meeting. Over the years a great many different people attended G^3, and it has become well-known for a unique friendly atmosphere which helped foster interactions of established and junior mathematicians, jump-start careers and collaborations, and build the sense of community in geometric group theory.

The conference website is http://www.math.uiuc.edu/~mineyev/ggg/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 20th Geometric Groups on the Gulf Coast Conference (abbreviated G3) was planned for March 22–24rd of 2018. Since the grant request was decilned by the NSF, there were no activities during 2018. The balance is being returned to NSF. No future G3s are planned.

To satisfy the 200 word minimum requirement here is some background on G3. Since its inception G3 has helped train graduate students and junior mathematicians, and will increase participation of traditionally underrepresented groups in Mathematics and related fields. The Gulf Coast does not see that many mathematical conferences, so by bringing to the area a
geographically diverse group of experts, G3 had  have a considerable impact on student training and faculty development. A distinctive feature of G3 is its waterfront location. G3 gave an opportunity for students to give a 50-minute-lecture to experts in the field. It is perhaps appropriate to add that students’ talks at G3 are nearly always of high quality. Some speakers were invited to give two talks: a research talk, and a more introductory talk addressed to students, researchers from neighboring fields, and general mathematical audience. This helped facilitate interactions between various fields and ease the
entry into the field for the newcomers.
